content: The "Promoting Health for Future Generations Act of 2007" increases the contribution limitation for Health Savings Accounts (HSAs) under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Medicare and VA healthcare enrollees are now eligible to contribute to HSAs. The "Promoting Health for Future Generations Act of 2007" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to allow Medicare and VA healthcare enrollees to contribute to Health Savings Accounts (HSAs). The "Promoting Health for Future Generations Act of 2007" allows Medicare and VA healthcare enrollees to contribute to Health Savings Accounts (HSAs), effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. SEC. 4 of the "Promoting Health for Future Generations Act of 2007" expands the age limitation for additional contributions to Health Savings Accounts (HSAs) from 55 to 50 years old. It also increases the contribution limits to $2,000. The effective date for these changes is taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. Individuals eligible for reimbursement under a spouse's flexible spending arrangement are not considered covered under a health plan merely because they are covered under a flexible spending arrangement maintained by the spouse's employer, as long as the employer is not the individual's employer and the individual certifies to this effect. The amendments made by this section regarding reimbursement under a flexible spending arrangement apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. SEC. 6 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow Medicare supplemental policies as qualified medical expenses. SEC. 7 introduces a new section allowing deductions for premiums of high deductible health plans. The section allows deductions for premiums paid by individuals under a high deductible health plan if they are eligible individuals. Eligible individuals are defined as those described in section 223(c)(1) and include the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. The term "high deductible health plan" is defined in section 223(c)(2). Deduction limits apply, allowing deductions for only one plan. In cases where an individual is covered by multiple high deductible health plans, only the amounts paid for the plan with the lowest premium can be considered for deduction. If multiple individuals are covered by a plan but only one is eligible, only 50 percent of the eligible individual's premiums can be taken into account. No deduction allowed for an individual under subsection (a) for coverage under a high deductible health plan if participating in a group health plan. Individual health insurance not considered a group health plan if it is a high deductible health plan or a payment by an employer/employee organization for such plan. The text discusses exceptions to the rule that disallows deductions for individuals under a high deductible health plan if they are part of a group health plan. Exceptions include coverage consisting only of contributions to a health savings account and certain permitted coverage under a group health plan. The text outlines exceptions to the rule disallowing deductions for individuals under a high deductible health plan if they are part of a group health plan. Exceptions include coverage involving contributions to a health savings account and specific permitted coverage under a group health plan. The text discusses deductions for high deductible health plans, allowing individuals to deduct premiums under section 224. Coordination with other deductions is also addressed in the amendments. The amendments in section 224 allow for deductions of premiums for high deductible health plans starting after December 31, 2007. Additionally, safe harbor rules for deductibles are being modified for these plans. The amendments in section 224 of the Internal Revenue Code allow for deductions of premiums for high deductible health plans starting after December 31, 2007. This includes changes to deductible limits for prescribed drugs and preventive care under family coverage. The Internal Revenue Code amendments in section 224 allow deductions for high deductible health plans, including changes to deductible limits for prescribed drugs and preventive care under family coverage. Additionally, a special rule for family coverage ensures that a health plan providing family coverage meets requirements by setting aggregate and individual deductible limits. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. SEC. 9 amends the Social Security Act to exempt MSA plans from having a deductible for preventive care. SEC. 10 allows individual contributions to Medicare Advantage MSA starting January 1, 2008. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows contributions by or for the account holder for the taxable year, not exceeding the difference between the annual deductible for the MSA plan and contributions described in subparagraph (A). The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. SEC. 11. Allowing MSA and HSA rollover to adult child of account holder. SEC. 11. Allowing MSA and HSA rollover to adult child of account holder. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include adult children in the treatment after the death of the account holder for Medical Savings Accounts (MSAs) and Health Savings Accounts (HSAs). Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include adult children in the treatment after the death of the account holder for Health Savings Accounts (HSAs). The term 'adult child' is defined in section 220(f)(8)(C). The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. SEC. 12 permits Medicare Advantage MSA funds to be used for wellness and fitness programs, with qualified medical expenses now including amounts paid to a gym for enrollment in such programs. This amendment applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007.
